article.description: Nine minutes into the second half, Kansas looked like it might follow one of the worst weeks in its history with one of its biggest upset losses.
article.headline: Scrappy Baylor wilts during second-half run
article.linkText: Red duds help Kansas stop losing skid
article.story: LAWRENCE, Kan. (AP) -- Nine minutes into the second half, Kansas looked like it might follow one of the worst weeks in its history with one of its biggest upset losses. Then J.R. Giddens hit two crowd-pleasing 3-pointers to start a 17-4 run and send the Jayhawks (No. 20 ESPN/USA Today, No. 21 AP) and their relieved fans to a 74-54 victory Wednesday over Baylor. "It felt like those two 3's really got us going," Giddens said. "Then we started attacking their zone a little better and got down the court a little quicker," Before Gidden's 3-pointers, the Jayhawks were 0-for-8 from behind the arc. Kansas led only 39-37 when Carl Marshall, playing with four fouls, hit a six-footer in the lane. But with several players in foul trouble and only six scholarship athletes available, the Bears finally began to wilt after the Jayhawks' offense got going. Wayne Simien had 24 points, Keith Langford added 19 and Giddens 15 for the Jayhawks (16-6, 8-3 Big 12). "The second half when Giddens hit those 3's is when the game changed," Baylor's Terrance Thomas said. "He is a great freshman. Those 3's opened it up so much inside." The Bears (7-17, 2-9), left with only six available scholarship athletes, played a slow and deliberate halfcourt offense and stifled the Jayhawks with a tight zone defense through the first nine minutes of the second half. "They just kept running guys in and out," Baylor's R. T. Guinn said. "We got a little fatigued out there." Kansas coach Bill Self said the Jayhawks made no radical second-half adjustments. "We just didn't make shots," he said. "Then J.R. made those two 3's and that made them spread it out." Simien, who scored the Kansas' first six points of the second half, had a putback to start the decisive run that ended with Giddens' driving layup for a 56-41 lead with 7:33 left. "I recommend if you ever have six scholarship players, you don't get in foul trouble," Baylor coach Scott Drew said. "Next time we will try to set up this game with Kansas at 30 minutes." Fans were already restless after the Jayhawks, under first-year head coach Bill Self, had lost by 20 points at No. 7 Oklahoma State and 19 at Nebraska last week. It was the first time since 1919 Kansas had consecutive losses of at least 19 points. Terrance Thomas had 15 points and Harvey Thomas added 13 for Baylor, which lost its third straight against ranked teams. The Bears lost 84-58 to No. 11 Texas on Feb. 10, and 91-58 at No. 7 Oklahoma State on Saturday. "I have a lot of respect for those guys," Simien said. "They played us really hard, and smart. We had a lot of trouble with that zone all the way through the first half." Baylor immediately quieted the sellout crowd by hitting five of its first seven shots. Kansas led by as many as six points twice in the first half, but the Bears' Matt Sayman hit a pair of free throws to tie it at 28 with 2:51 left. Kansas then closed the first half with a 5-0 run to take a 33-28 halftime lead.
